Award.AwardTitle: Counting and Sieving in Group Orbits
Award.AbstractNarration:
Counting primes or numbers with few prime factors in growing sets of integers is a class of problem in number theory which has been studied for centuries: one of the most basic incarnations of this is determining approximately the number of primes less than a given number, and its answer is the prime number theorem. One can consider higher dimensional versions of this type of question: for example, how many Pythagorean triples (positive integers with x^2+y^2=z^2) with hypotenuse at most Z have area with at most 10 prime factors? This particular question can be phrased in terms of counting points (x,y,z) for which xy/2 has at most 10 prime factors in an orbit of a certain group acting on (3,4,5). In this problem, the group involved is "big" and one can use classical methods to approach it. However, in the case where the underlying group is "thin" (as it is in the beautiful theory of Apollonian packings), one must appeal to much more modern tools, namely the Affine Sieve developed by Bourgain-Gamburd-Sarnak in 2011. The PI proposes to study not only the arithmetic properties of orbits of specific interesting groups (such as the Apollonian group), but also to investigate properties of thin groups in general: for example, how does one tell if a given matrix group is thin? Should one expect a random finitely generated matrix group to be thin? These questions toy with undecidability and require an intricate combination of tools from various fields -- geometry, number theory, combinatorics -- to tackle. In addition the PI proposes to develop several computer programs to determine the answers to some of these and related questions with high accuracy.

Thin subgroups of GL(n,Z) are those which are of infinite index in the Z-points of their Zariski closure in GL(n,C). In contrast to arithmetic groups, the counterparts to thin groups which are prevalent, say, in the theory of automorphic forms, there are many unanswered core questions on thin groups which are essential in applications to the number theory of thin groups. A pressing such question is how to tell if a given finitely generated group is thin, as well as whether thin groups are generic in some sense. These two questions have been answered in a few situations, and the PI proposes to answer them in much higher generality. The PI seeks to answer these questions in the subclass of thin monodromy groups. Furthermore, the PI's proposed program will delve deeply into the geometry inherent to the groups in question, proving various theorems on thin groups which will bring them more in line with what is known on arithmetic groups. The PI also seeks to develop various computer algorithms which would predict various properties of a group given its generators, from Zariski density to thinness. Keeping in mind that the motivation for the current interest in thin groups stems from number theory, the PI also proposes to work on the arithmetic side of thin groups, generalizing some of the PI's previous results about the Apollonian group to a much larger class of groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During her three years of funding, the PI had set out to gain a better understanding of thin matrix good, particularly from the number theoretic point of view.  This is a fairly new area of research: up until around 2007, most number theoretic problems involved groups that were not thin: for example, the famous statement that elliptic curves are modular which led to the proof of Fermat's last theorem in the mid 1990's can be thought of as a statement connected to non-thin subgroups of the special linear group.  

The PI's research sheds light on the fact that thin groups in number theory have many of the same rich properties that number theorists have discovered and used about non-thin  groups. One aspect of this is to work on concrete arithmetic problems involving objects with thin symmetry groups.  A good example of such a problem is that of the arithmetic of Apollonian circle packings.  Apollonian packings, obtained by starting with three pairwise tangent circles and adding in all circles tangent to all those three, and then continuing to add in circles tangent to triples of tangent circles in the picture (see Figure 1 for an example), were first studied in ancient Greece.  Only in the 1900's was it discovered that, first of all, if any quadruple of pairwise tangent circles in the packing have integer curvature -- which is the reciprocal of the radius) -- then all of the circles in the packing have integer curvature, as can be seen in Figure 1 which includes curvatures of all circles depicted; and, second of all, that the curvatures in any Apollonian packing can be realized as coming from an orbit of a thin matrix group. Essentially, this means that studying the curvatures in Apollonian packings boils down to studying arithmetic properties of a particular thin group.

In recent years, many new Apollonian-like packings have been discovered, for example, by Katherine Stange.  One of the PI's main works over the past 3 years was, together with Katherine Stange and Xin Zhang, to come up with a criterion for the packings in order to have a "local-global principle" which essentially allows one to determine all the curvatures in a given packing just by listing all integers which have a pre-prescribed remainder upon division by an easily computable integer depending on the packing: a very strong arithmetic property. Such a local to global principle had been proven previously by Bourgain-Kontorovich for Apollonian packings and by Zhang for Apollonian 3-packings. The PI and her co-authors proved the existence of such a local to global principle for infinitely many Apollonian-like packings. See Figure 2 for an example of such a packing that is not Apollonian.

The PI has also worked on studying prime components, or chains of circles connected by tangencies, all of which have prime curvature, through the fourth Women in Numbers workshop in which she co-led together with Damaris Schindler and Katherine Stange a group of young female number theorists -- Holley Friedlander, Piper Harron, and Catherine Hsu. In this work, the PI and her co-authors embarked on the much more difficult task of studying special subsets of orbits of thin groups, yielding some interesting results on the number of primes bounded by some real number in a given prime component, and even more interesting conjectures based on data they generated.

Finally, the PI has studied how Apollonian packings and the Apollonian group can be used to come up with good rational approximations to complex numbers together with Sneha Chaubey, Robert Hines, and Katherine Stange: a very different angle on studying the arithmetic of Apollonian packings.

Another side of the PI's work has been to study thin groups in their own right, arithmetic considerations aside. One big achievement in this area over the last three years has been to show together with her co-author Igor Rivin that, with an appropriate definition of "generic," 2-generator thin subgroups of SL_n(Z) are generic, or, put very roughly, if you pick such a group out of a hat, it will most likely be thin: even more reason to study them and gain a better understanding of them.  Along the same lines, the PI has come up with similar results for thin subgroups of other classical groups of Lie type together with co-authors Sneha Chaubey and Amita Malik.

Throughout the past three years, the PI's research has had a broader impact on the mathematical community and beyond.  As described above, she has worked at length with young female mathematicians in an effort to further their careers and bridge the gender gap in mathematics. Furthermore, she has developed an outreach program called M-PACT to a local underprivileged school in which she brings mathematics, sometimes connected to her research, to underprivileged students with the help of other members of her department.
